docs.lead_paragraph: Before she was first lady or senator, Hillary Clinton was a corporate lawyer.
docs.abstract: Before she was first lady or senator, Hillary Clinton was a corporate lawyer. In fact, she spent the longest stretch of her professional life in a corporate law firm - which explains a lot, says Susan Lehman, writing in The American Lawyer. Corporate lawyers, says Ms. Lehman, are professionally risk-averse; relentlessly, unreasonably reasonable; and trained [...]

docs.lead_paragraph: Watching Robert Torricelli mist and mewl, as he was torn from the bosom of the Senate, gave me new pause over that old question: Are men biologically suited to hold political office and leadership positions? We have the Torch dousing himself in self-pity and wondering why nobody will forgive him for something he claims he never did with a sugar daddy who draped him in Italian-made clothes and Tiffany baubles.
docs.abstract: Maureen Dowd Op-Ed column says Sen Hillary Rodham Clinton is being less vocal that many of her fellow Democrats in expressing reservations about confronting Iraq, perhaps because she intends to run for president in 2008; says Clinton knows that any woman who hopes to be elected president cannot afford to be seen as too much of a dove (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Name: Howard Wolfson Age: 33 Coming from: Washington Looking for: A victory When Howard Wolfson, Hillary Clinton's communications director, moved to New York last summer, he couldn't face the local hazing ritual known as the Manhattan apartment hunt. Clinton's listening tour had just begun, and Wolfson was the sole person juggling scores of calls a day, piling up stacks of messages from international media outlets he had never even heard of. Taking a few hours off to scout an overrated Upper West Side brownstone didn't seem like the most efficient use of his time. So when Wolfson wasn't on the road with Clinton, he did what new arrivals to New York have always done: he crashed on friends' couches. He lived out of a beat-up garment bag that contained a laptop, a dour-looking stuffed animal called Telly Monster (''He's one of Elmo's friends'') and a few changes of clothes. The frequent reappearances in his wardrobe did not go unnoticed. When one of the first lady's Secret Service agents gave Wolfson identification pins, he told him, ''I'm giving you two -- one for each of your suits.''
docs.abstract: Profile of Howard Wolfson, Hillary Clinton's communications director, who moved to New York City last summer; he comments on his city experiences; photo (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Sebastian de Grazia (Op-Ed, Nov. 25) asks whether we should continue to pay for Hillary Clinton's services as first lady now that she has announced her intention to run for the Senate from New York. But should Rudolph W. Giuliani be required to resign as New York City's mayor before he enters the Senate race?
docs.abstract: Letter from Irving Schreiber on question of whether Hillary Clinton's services as first lady should be paid as she campaigns to run for Senate from New York; says it is common practice for holder of political office to run for another office, witness Mayor Rudolph W Giuliani (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: OTHER than paying taxes or getting stuck in an elevator, there is probably nothing more universally dreaded than going on a blind date arranged by one's parents. Two years ago, Hillary Mara Kimmelman and William Jay Solomon were set up by Miss Kimmelman's father, Lawrence, and Mr. Solomon's mother, Barbara, who had been high school classmates in Long Beach, N.Y. The old friends -- he was a football player, she a cheerleader -- spoke on the telephone after being out of touch for many years.
docs.abstract: Hillary Mara Kimmelman and William Jay Solomon, former high school classmates from Long Beach, NY, are married; photo (M)
